grammar.title: Emphatic Discourse Marker
grammar.description: The term 'o' functions as an emphatic discourse marker at the end of a clause, emphasizing the truth or implying empathy.
examples: He is a good person o.

grammar.title: Copula 'Na'
grammar.description: The word 'na' acts as a copula in Kenyan English, often highlighting or emphasizing the following constituent.
examples: Na im make the party sweet.

grammar.title: Relative Pronoun 'Whose' Avoidance
grammar.description: The relative pronoun 'whose' is frequently replaced with 'that' in Kenyan English.
examples: The man that I bought a car from went to Mombasa last week.
The woman that got her purse stolen went to the police.

grammar.title: Articles Omission and Usage
grammar.description: Articles are sometimes omitted where needed, and 'the' is used in unconventional instances, especially with uncountable nouns.
examples: I stepped in the mud on my way home.

grammar.title: Pluralization of Uncountable Nouns
grammar.description: Certain uncountable nouns, like 'data' or 'equipment,' are pluralized, more prevalent among specific social classes and rural areas.

grammar.title: British English Spelling Usage
grammar.description: In written Kenyan English, British English spellings are frequently preferred over American English spellings.

grammar.title: Progressive Aspect Use
grammar.description: Kenyan English employs the progressive aspect with 'is' or 'are' along with the '-ing' form of verbs more frequently.

phonetics.title: Vowel Mergers
phonetics.description: Vowel mergers occur, leading to the homophony of specific words like 'cot,' 'caught,' and 'cut.'

phonetics.title: Diphthong Simplification
phonetics.description: Diphthong /əu/ in words like 'low' is simplified to /u/.

phonetics.title: Long Vowel Shift
phonetics.description: The long /i:/ vowel sound changes to /e/.

phonetics.title: Consonant Alterations
phonetics.description: Changes in consonant sounds such as the voicing of /p/ to /b/.

phonetics.title: Fricative Changes
phonetics.description: Interdental fricatives shift to alveolar plosives.

phonetics.title: Final Consonant Reduction
phonetics.description: Reduction of final consonants and devoicing of voiced consonants.

phonetics.title: Fricative Realization
phonetics.description: Voiced and voiceless fricatives are realized differently.

grammar.title: Sense Verbs Distinction
grammar.description: Distinct use of sense verbs in Cameroonian English, such as substituting 'hear' for 'smell' influenced by native languages.
examples: Using 'hear' instead of 'smell' due to native language influence.

grammar.title: Position of Interrogatives
grammar.description: Interrogatives like 'who,' 'what,' and 'where' are placed at the end in Cameroonian English, varying based on formality and speaker's education level.

grammar.title: Omission of Determiner 'the'
grammar.description: The absence of the determiner 'the' in Cameroonian languages influences its omission before nouns in Cameroon English.

grammar.title: Resumptive Pronoun Usage
grammar.description: Usage of resumptive pronouns not only after focused nouns but also within relative clauses in Cameroonian English.
examples: The car I like, it's fast.

grammar.title: Universal Tag Question 'na'
grammar.description: In Cameroonian English, a universal tag question 'na' is employed irrespective of subject, tense, or person in the sentence.
